Sketching in code.

[...] proficiency in a craft is essential to every artist. Therein lies the prime source of creative imagination. Walter Gropius - The Bauhaus Manifesto

All design artifacts go through a translation when they move from paper or pixels to code.

As a designer you want to play an active role in that translation.

Today we're going to explore how we give an experience style & structure.

Style & structure are two of the four major components that make up web experiences.

Contentcopy, data, images, video

Structure

Style

Action

When we talk about the web platform, html gives structure to content and css gives it style.

html

Hyper Text Markup Language

html's standardized tag structure is what makes the internet possible.

It provides a common language that all pages adhere to. Without this there would be no search or linking.

Here's what the first website looked like.


<p>This is a paragraph tag.</p>


<!-- tags can nest. here's an unordered list -->
<ul>
  <li>list item one</li>
  <li>list item two</li>
  <li>list item three</li>
</ul>

Try it on CodePen

http://bit.ly/1RJSK80

The # of html tags is limited when you consider the amount of variation on the internet.

You won't find a tag for every structural element or UI component.

Some tags affect the visual appearance of content in the browser.

<button>this is a button</button>
<input type='text' value='this is a text input'/>
<select>
  <optgroup>
    <option>this is a select</option>
  </optgroup>
</select>

Most tags don't have any specific visual traits associated with them. They exist to wrap your content and give it meaningful structure. That's important for things like search engines that crawl sites to understand what is being presented to the user.

this is a nav
this is a header
this is an article
this is a footer
<nav>this is a nav</nav>
<header>this is a header</header>
<article>this is an article</article>
<footer>this is a footer</footer>

Browsers aren't too strict when it comes to interpreting your html. As long as your document is well formed the browser will probably roll with it.

<!-- 
the h1 doesn't have a closing tag
the browser will get confused 
the h2 picks up the h1 formatting
but nothing explodes
-->
<h1>headline
<h2>subhead</h2>
this is a dog this is a cat 
<!-- 
i invented some tags
it's bad practice
but nothing explodes
-->
<dog>this is a dog</dog>
<cat>this is a cat</cat>

css

Cascading Style Sheets

css adds color, typography, page composition and animation to the web.

If we didn't have css, everything would look like craigslist.

css works by selecting elements on the page and applying styles to them.


/* this is a css rule for a paragraph tag */
p{
  font-size: 32px;
  color: #cc3300;
}
